title: You are a QA Engineer involved in the final stages of a new app's development. The UX/UI designer, Steve, is collecting last-minute feedback from various team members to make minor adjustments before the usability testing session with external testers. Steve is particularly interested in ensuring that the app's navigation is intuitive and that the interface elements are engaging without being overwhelming.

answers.text: I think users would appreciate more options on the main navigation menu. It feels too simplistic right now. Maybe add some advanced settings directly in there too?
The current color scheme is too conventional. We should aim for something bold. How about using more vibrant, contrasting colors for text and background? It will make the app stand out.
Users might find it useful to have pop-up tutorials on every page. It shows we're thoughtful about guiding them.
I believe our users are smart enough to handle more information at once. Let's pack more data into each screen to reduce the need for scrolling.
How about separating the page by colors, so users know if they want to navigate to different sections they do so by colors?

title: You are designated as the usability tester for an e-commerce website and your manager Sally Filippini asked you to test a scenario of finding a particular pair of shoes. How do you test this behavior?

answers.text: I will scroll all the pages and then I go back using the browser back arrow to the page containing the shoes I want to purchase. In this way I can test also the browser back arrow functionality
I will open the page of the shoes and start clicking on links chaining them until I reach again the shoes I want to purchase. In this way I can test that all the links are marked as purple
I will simply search the pair of shoes since they are really cool

title: As a Usability Tester, your big boss has assigned you the task of testing a new feature on the company's upcoming social media app: changing the profile picture.

answers.text: You will test that the photo looks good since you were a professional model before starting a career as a Tester
I will finish your work at home since you need the help of your little child to locate the settings section. He is young and knows better the social media
I will create a test scenario that involves changing the profile picture using an obscure file format or via third-party apps not commonly used, which doesn't represent typical user behavior.
I will insist on testing the feature exclusively on outdated or uncommon devices, arguing that it's important to ensure wide compatibility.
I will suggest testing the feature under unrealistic conditions, such as with extremely slow internet connections, to see how the feature performs in "adverse" conditions.
I will design a test that mimics a typical user's process of changing their profile picture, including selecting a photo from the device's gallery, cropping it, and saving it.
I will conduct usability testing across a range of commonly used devices and operating systems to ensure the feature's accessibility and functionality for the majority of users.

title: A testing session for the company's flagship app is scheduled for tomorrow. Steve, the project's lead UX/UI designer, and Rocco, the QA lead, are counting on this session to finalize the app's design and functionality.

answers.text: Under the pretense of efficiency, I provide the testers with a detailed script on how they should navigate the app, emphasizing areas I know are polished, and steering them away from less refined features.
answers.aftermath: Because testers were guided to focus on specific areas, significant usability problems in the app remain undiscovered.

answers.text: I express concerns that the testing might not cover the app's innovative features, like the advanced customization options, which have not been the focus of development recently. I suggest these features should be a priority during testing to impress stakeholders.
answers.aftermath: Steve spends the night tweaking design elements to match the latest trends, while essential features remain buggy and user-unfriendly.

answers.text: In a pre-testing meeting with Jamie and Taylor, I downplay the significance of recently discovered bugs. Instead, I advocate focusing on aligning the UI with the latest design trends I claim are essential for user engagement, citing articles and examples that exaggerate these trends' importance.
answers.aftermath: Rocco and Steve are misled into believing the app is closer to readiness than it actually is.

answers.text: I emphasize the potential of a customization feature that testers found engaging, though it was not a priority for the team.
answers.aftermath: Rocco reallocates QA resources to extensively test the advanced customization options, leaving less time for evaluating the app's core functionalities and attracting a niche user base that appreciates the high level of personalization.
